item.title: Best Dance Performances of 2025
item.description: Twyla Tharp led the way with her distinct brand of American classicism, along with other artists who stepped it up.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas, Brian Seibert and Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:credit: Julieta Cervantes for The New York Times

item.title: Golden Globe Nominations Confirm the Allure of Warner Bros.
item.description: The studio’s film “One Battle After Another,” and an HBO show it owns, “The White Lotus,” scored the most nominations for movies and television shows.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.category: Only Murders in the Building (TV Program)

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Snubs and Surprises: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Misses a Major Nomination
item.description: Though its stars are up for acting prizes, the film is not in the running for best musical or comedy, only for box office achievement.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Collector Surrenders ‘Nude Emperor’ Statue Identified as Looted
item.description: The statue and a marble head of a Greek orator seized from the Met Museum were among dozens of items found to have been looted that were handed over to Turkey at a ceremony in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg and Graham Bowley

item.title: 6 Memorable Moments From the ‘Trump Kennedy Center’ Honors
item.description: President Trump expressed his love of “Phantom of the Opera,” got in more digs at Jimmy Kimmel and joked — perhaps — about adding his name to the arts center he has taken over.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before the Kennedy Center Honors ceremony on Sunday, President Trump had taken an unusually direct role in choosing the honorees.

item.title: Golden Globe 2026 Nominees: Full List Including ‘One Battle After Another’
item.description: The movies and TV series competing for the 83rd Golden Globes. The ceremony will air on Jan. 11.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Leonardo DiCaprio, left, and Benicio Del Toro in “One Battle After Another,” nominated for nine Golden Globes.

item.title: For Martin Parr, ‘Showing Things as They Are’ Was Art
item.description: Some saw cynicism in the photographer’s pictures of everyday life in Britain during his nearly six-decade career. But he said he wanted to honor the ordinary.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge

item.title: Fall for Modern Dance With This Masterpiece
item.description: Joyful, melancholy, heroic: Paul Taylor’s “Esplanade” celebrates its 50th anniversary and the extraordinariness of ordinary movement.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Christine Baranski and ‘A Christmas Carol’: A Natural Pairing
item.description: On a recent recording, and in concerts this month, Baranski reads Dickens’s holiday classic with the Skylark Vocal Ensemble.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine Baranski reading from Charles Dickens’s manuscript for “A Christmas Carol” at the Morgan Library and Museum.

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’: Madeleine Stowe on Playing Evil’s Little Helper
item.description: “It spoke to me about these particular times that we’re living in,” the actress said about her first screen role in several years.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

item.title: Skate Story Follows a Glass Demon’s Grinding, Gratifying Quest
item.description: The solo developer behind Skate Story pitched his underworld trek to publishers as Tony Hawk’s Journey Dark Souls.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter

item.title: Review: Two New Bach Pieces? The Real Thrill Was in the Chase.
item.description: Two workmanlike pieces by the teenage Bach had their New York premiere at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.category: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

item.title: I Hit the Art Basel Superfecta
item.description: But what was the payout? A critic survives the four-season journey to the premium art fair in Hong Kong, Basel, Paris and now Miami Beach. Here are his takeaways.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Sean Zanni/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jesús Rafael Soto’s ‘‘Pénétrable’’ installation, made of suspended plastic or metal tubes, at the preview on Dec. 3 of Art Basel Miami Beach.

item.title: At Alvin Ailey, a Caribbean Folk Tale Inspires a Dance About Love
item.description: The first week of the company’s annual season at City Center featured “Jazz Island,” an earnest premiere by Maija García, and a treasure by Alonzo King.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:description: Coral Dolphin dances the role of Erzulie, the goddess of love, a central figure in Afro-Caribbean folklore and in Maija García’s “Jazz Island” by Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

item.title: Jeremy O. Harris Is Released From Custody in Japan
item.description: The Tony-nominated playwright was arrested last month on suspicion of attempted drug smuggling. He was released on Monday, Japanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: The Tony-nominated playwright and actor Jeremy O. Harris earlier this year.

item.title: ‘Marjorie Prime’ Review: A.I. Gave Her Back Her Husband. Was It Worth It?
item.description: June Squibb stars in the Broadway premiere of Jordan Harrison’s meditation on grief and the nature of human and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: June Squibb, right, plays the titular character of “Marjorie Prime,” with Christopher Lowell as an A.I. replica of her deceased husband as he was in his 30s.

item.title: At the Kennedy Center Honors, Little Glitz and One Striking Accessory
item.description: Melania Trump went minimal, Gloria Gaynor dressed to shine, but the star of the night was the president.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, arriving for the Kennedy Center Honors on Sunday.

item.title: ‘The End of an Era,’ and 7 Other Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The first two episodes of Taylor Swift’s documentary series air, and “South Park” wraps up its 28th season.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Taylor Swift during the Eras Tour, which wrapped up in Vancouver last year.

item.title: 8 Matisse Works Stolen From Library in Brazil
item.description: Two armed men stole over a dozen pieces of art from a São Paulo exhibition featuring works by the French painter and other artists.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A police car in front of the Mario de Andrade Library in São Paulo, Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1, Episode 7 Recap: Inferno
item.description: The town experiences a tragedy of new proportions. The lead perpetrator this time isn’t Pennywise.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

item.title: Trump Hosts the Kennedy Center Honors, Breaking Tradition
item.description: Past presidents have attended the marquee event, but on Sunday Mr. Trump was the first to host it, putting his cultural takeover of Washington in sharp relief.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

item.title: Fern Michaels, Prolific Author of Romance Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: In her 40s, the self-described New Jersey housewife started building a women’s fiction empire, churning out dozens of popular books.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Katy Perry Posts Photos With Justin Trudeau Amid Romance Rumors
item.description: Ms. Perry and Mr. Trudeau, the former prime minister of Canada, posed together in photos and videos on Instagram, making them “Instagram official.”
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press, Miguel a Lopes, via EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Martin Parr Dies at 73; Photographed Britain’s Unvarnished Quirks
item.description: Calling his work “subjective documentary,” he seemed to take an almost anthropological delight in chronicling the absurdities of human behavior.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: A 2007 Martin Parr self-portrait. “You should ask yourself why we are so used to seeing glamorized pictures of what people think they should look like,” he said, adding that most images were “some form of propaganda.”

item.title: Colin Jost Plays Pete Hegseth on ‘S.N.L.’ to Explain ‘Operation Kill Everybody’
item.description: Jost appeared as the defense secretary in a rare role away from the Weekend Update desk while Melissa McCarthy hosted for the first time since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:description: Colin Jost was brimming with pent-up energy as Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth.

item.title: From Improv Class to Mayor-Elect: Zohran Mamdani’s Cultural Influences
item.description: In an interview, he revealed the Indian ragas, indie movies, comedy shows and museums in the city that stayed with him.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: In some ways, Zohran Mamdani’s cultural influences would be familiar to any New York City kid.

item.title: Best Songs of 2025
item.description: Listen to 48 tracks that broke new artists, blew apart genres and revived beloved sounds.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Book Review: ‘Television,’ by Lauren Rothery
item.description: Lauren Rothery’s “Television” finds an action star and two writers dazed by the changing rules of the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

item.title: The Big Apple Circus Returns to New York With Its Show-Stealing Dogs
item.description: Copo, Diana, Suzy, Tomasa, Lana, Riso and Charlotte dance and prance inside the big tent.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Amy Lombard

item.title: Gift-Worthy Holiday Art Books
item.description: This season’s bounty includes volumes on far-out artists, unusual cats and enviable gardens.
item.dc:creator: Leah Greenblatt

item.title: Francis Ford Coppola’s F.P. Journe Sells for $11 Million at Auction
item.description: Frenzied bidding pushed the polarizing F.P. Journe timepiece into near-record territory despite one dealer calling the design “goofy.”
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein

item.title: Guy Cogeval, Boundary-Pushing Museum Director, Dies at 70
item.description: His innovative approach drew crowds to the Musée d’Orsay, one of France’s flagship cultural institutions, which he led from 2008 to 2017.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Frank Gehry’s Buildings Sound as Marvelous as They Look
item.description: Gehry, who died on Friday at 96, made an invaluable contribution to classical music by designing spaces with stunning acoustics.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.category: Fisher, Richard B, Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College
item.media:credit: View Pictures/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The swooping interior of Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.

item.title: With ‘Five Nights at Freddy’s 2’ and ‘I Love L.A.,’ Josh Hutcherson Is Back
item.description: The “Five Nights at Freddy’s” and “I Love L.A.” star found instant success as a child actor. After his “Hunger Games” fame, it felt like it almost all went away.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: “As a kid, I never wanted to leave set,” Hutcherson said about his early acting years.

item.title: A Forensic Artist Brings the Protagonist of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s “The School of Night” to Life
item.description: The pair work together to envision Kristian Hadeland, the protagonist of the author’s latest novel, “The School of Night.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Comita

item.title: Danny Brown Is Proud of His New Beats and Gym Physique
item.description: The rapper chats about the experimental pop collaborators and healthy habits that fueled his sixth album, “Stardust.”
item.dc:creator: Ross Scarano
item.media:credit: Jason Bollenbacher/SXSW Conference & Festivals, via Getty Images

item.title: The Area 51 of New England
item.description: Through trinkets and tales, a U.F.O. story that once captured national attention lives on.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and John Tully

item.title: Bublé for a Day, but He Can’t Sing and There’s Little Resemblance
item.description: Dan Perlman, a comedian, looks and sounds nothing like Michael Bublé. And yet, for some reason, he was hired to impersonate the crooner at a birthday party.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:description: Dan Perlman, a writer and comedian, was game, if bemused, when he was drafted to appear as the singer Michael Bublé at a stranger’s 60th birthday party.

item.title: Frank Gehry, the Disrupter, Opened Their Imaginations
item.description: Architects, artists, clients and partners assess his life and impact over eight decades.
item.dc:creator: Sam Lubell
item.media:description: Frank Gehry in 1988 in front of his famed Santa Monica, Calif., house, its Dutch Colonial core wrapped with a combination of chain-link fencing, corrugated metal, and off-kilter windows and beams.

item.title: Erik Bulatov, Russian Painter Who Undermined Soviet Propaganda, Dies at 92
item.description: For years he lived a double life, secretly making anti-Communist paintings. He found fame in the late 1980s, once his work was shown outside the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Red Horizon by Erik Bulatov

item.title: Frank Gehry: 12 Essential, Stunning Projects
item.description: A singular genius, Gehry redefined architecture with joyful buildings like the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.media:description: The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Spain is a game-changing, fish-shaped art museum on the waterfront.

item.title: Library Agency Reinstates Grants Canceled by Trump Administration
item.description: The Institute of Museum and Library Services restored the funding after a federal court ruled that moves to dismantle the agency were unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.category: Institute of Museum and Library Services
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Institute of Museum and Library Services, which last year issued nearly $270 million in grants for libraries, museums and archives.

item.title: Frank Gehry, Titan of Architecture, Is Dead at 96
item.description: He designed some of the world’s most recognizable buildings, notably the spectacular Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, his masterpiece.
item.dc:creator: Nicolai Ouroussoff
item.media:description: Frank Gehry en 2003, en una ceremonia de inauguración de la Sala de Conciertos Walt Disney de Los Ángeles, uno de los muchos edificios célebres que diseñó en todo el mundo.

item.title: ‘A Christmas Carol’ Review: A Gentle Interpretation of a Classic
item.description: This production, which retains many of the charms of its 2019 Broadway staging, has lost some of its necessary darkness.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman
item.category: Perelman, Ronald O, Performing Arts Center
item.media:description: Michael Cerveris as Ebenezer Scrooge in a revival of Jack Thorne’s “A Christmas Carol” at the Perelman Performing Arts Center in Manhattan.

item.title: Dancing Babies and Toddlers Are Teaching the Pros a Thing or Two
item.description: Everyone loves tiny dancers. Now some artists are considering why they bring us such joy — and what lessons they might have for grown-ups.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Fuhrer

item.title: 20 Holiday Romance Movies to Stream Now: ‘Love Actually,’ ‘Serendipity’ and More
item.description: From timeless classics to frothy distractions, we’ve picked the best holiday romances currently available to stream.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s movies include cosmopolitan assassins, flesh-slicing swashbucklers and seasoned supernatural detectives.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: The Pittsburgh Symphony Plays How an Orchestra Should Sound
item.description: Under its music director, Manfred Honeck, the ensemble returned to Carnegie Hall for the first time in over a decade, flying in on a high.
item.dc:creator: David Allen
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manfred Honeck, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra’s music director, who holds the ensemble to stratospherically high standards.

item.title: Austria Forms Panel to Study Its Rights to Famed Florentine Diamond
item.description: The Hapsburg family claims the gem, which it secretly kept hidden for decades.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Florentine Diamond, thought lost or stolen for more than a century, was actually secretly kept in a Canadian bank.

item.title: Fans Are Obsessed With This Celebrity Couple. They Star in ‘Zootopia.’
item.description: WildeHopps, a.k.a. the fox and bunny at the heart of the franchise, has inspired a YouTube movie, TikToks, fancams and more. The obsession goes deep (and sometimes weird).
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Nick Wilde (voiced by Jason Bateman) and Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) in “Zootopia 2.”

item.title: At the National Archives, a Deep Dive Into the American Story
item.description: A new $40-million exhibit, opening nine months after President Trump fired the chief archivist, uses technology to explore the 13 billion-plus items in its vaults.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opening gallery of “The American Story,” which features the 1823 copperplate engraving of the Declaration of Independence in one case and, beyond it, a handwritten copy of the Emancipation Proclamation.

item.title: Best Albums of 2025
item.description: The Korean pop outsider Effie and the Brooklyn indie-rock band Geese top our critics’ lists this year.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: 11 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘WTO/99’ Review: The ‘Battle in Seattle’ as Seen by the Participants
item.description: To tell the story of the demonstrations surrounding a World Trade Organization meeting, “WTO/99” assembled scenes shot by the participants themselves.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Spartacus: House of Ashur’ Resurrects a Cult Franchise
item.description: “Spartacus: House of Ashur,” premiering this month on Starz, brings the cult favorite 2010s action series back in an unlikely way.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.category: Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (TV Program)

item.title: What ‘Hamnet’ Lost (and Gained) on the Way From Page to Screen
item.description: The filmmaker Chloé Zhao and the novelist-turned-screenwriter Maggie O’Farrell explained the changes they made in the tale of Shakespeare, his wife and their son.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Best Jazz Albums of 2025
item.description: The most compelling releases of the year reimagined hip-hop tracks, deep-rooted collaborations and longstanding inspirations.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer

item.title: After ‘Working Girl,’ Can Christopher Ashley Bring His Sunshine to New York?
item.description: Before returning to New York to lead Roundabout, Christopher Ashley is concluding his 18-year tenure at La Jolla Playhouse with the new musical “Working Girl.”
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: He’s got the magic touch: Twenty shows that La Jolla Playhouse helped to develop during Christopher Ashley’s tenure have made their way to Broadway.

item.title: Jeremy O. Harris Is Arrested in Japan on Suspicion of Smuggling Drugs
item.description: The Tony-nominated American playwright and actor has been in custody since airport customs officers found Ecstasy in his bag last month.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: Jeremy O. Harris, the Tony-nominated playwright and actor, in September.

item.title: Dashing Through a Season of Holiday Movies
item.description: For one writer, putting together her annual roundup of streaming holiday movies requires open-mindedness — and a high tolerance for candy-coated clichés.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Thanks Trump for Google Superstardom in 2025
item.description: The host said he wouldn’t have been the third-most-trending person in Google searches this year “without the support of loyal viewers” like the president.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, ‘Mortal Kombat’ Actor, Dies at 75
item.description: The actor, born in Japan, starred in dozens of film and television shows, including Amazon’s “The Man in the High Castle.” His career spanned more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa in 2019.

item.title: Netflix to Buy Warner Bros in $83 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal to acquire the Hollywood behemoth’s television and film studios as well as HBO Max will bulk up the world’s biggest paid streaming service.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Netflix has never tried an acquisition even remotely close to this size.
